div.head: Education in History
div.p: In Praeterita, Ruskin declares that, in his home education, “history was never thought of, beyond what I chose to read of Scottʼs Tales of a Grandfather” (Ruskin, Works, 35:57). Indeed, literature must have framed much of Ruskinʼs historical learning, as did travel and the books associated with travel—landscape annuals, travel guides, and the like—along with what he saw of historical art, whether in reproduction or in the course of travel. These are of course dramatic means of learning about historical events, if not historiography, but these experiences probably were not as happenstance as Ruskin suggests in his autobiography. A deliberate plan of reading is indicated by John James Ruskinʼs lists of acquisitions for the family library.

A notable interest in history first appears in Ruskinʼs writing in 1828–29, when he recasts “The Ship” (1827) as “The Ship” (1828–29), remaking a poem that had been typical mainly of his absorption in visual relationships into one with a historical and patriotic emphasis, as well. Other works of 1828–29 reflect the newfound historical interest, and in particular the emphasis on heroism that held sway in John James Ruskinʼs book purchases in these years. In general, it might be said that Ruskinʼs Enlightenment, Edgeworthian education of 1826–27 acquires a romantic, historicized turn in 1828–29.

John James acquired Scottʼs Tales of a Grandfather as they were being released (1827–29), relating the history of Scotland to the Rebellion of 1745–46, in which the Young Pretender . Other Scott novels mentioned in John Jamesʼs expenditures at this time include Redgauntlet (1824), concerning the Young Pretender; Peveril of the Peak (1823), about the alleged anti-Catholic conspiracy against Charles II; Quentin Durward (1823), concerning the French court of Louis XI in the fifteenth century; and The Fortunes of Nigel (1822), revolving around the court of James I. The bias for biography is reflected also in a purchase of the Roman historian, Cornelius Nepos, whose surviving work consists largely of the lives of famous military commanders
